importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, marking the culmination of the National League Championship Series and the Dodgers' advancement to the World Series.
The date on which Game 4 of the NLCS took place, a pivotal moment in the postseason that led to the Dodgers' sweep and qualification for the World Series.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The immediate post-game celebration and the resulting team break before the World Series, emphasizing the significance of this game as a turning point.

keyTakeAways: Shohei Ohtani delivered one of the most remarkable single-game performances in postseason baseball history, hitting three home runs and throwing a scoreless, dominant 10-strikeout mound performance in Game 4 of the NLCS.
The Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Milwaukee Brewers 5-1, completing a four-game sweep and securing their return to the World Series.
Ohtani became the first player since 1886 to hit three home runs in a game as a starting pitcher, and the first pitcher in 87 years to achieve this feat.
Ohtani’s performance marked a historic milestone in MLB history, especially as a two-way player, with three home runs and 10 strikeouts in one game.
He is credited with earning the NLCS MVP award, highlighting his transformative performance despite a previous postseason slump.
The game highlighted the Dodgers’ team depth and consistency, with Ohtani acknowledging the contributions of teammates like Teoscar Hernández and Mookie Betts.

namedEntities.name: Shohei Ohtani
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Japanese-American professional baseball player and two-way superstar
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ohtani is the central figure of the article, delivering an unprecedented performance that defined the game and earned him the NLCS MVP award.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Major League Baseball team based in Los Angeles
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dodgers are the team that advanced to the World Series after defeating the Milwaukee Brewers in the NLCS, making this a pivotal team achievement.

namedEntities.name: Milwaukee Brewers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Major League Baseball team based in Milwaukee
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Brewers were the opposing team in the NLCS, and their loss to the Dodgers marked the end of their postseason run.

namedEntities.name: Dave Roberts
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Roberts provided commentary on Ohtani’s performance and emphasized the team’s collective effort and the significance of Ohtani’s comeback.

namedEntities.name: Teoscar Hernández
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hernández is referenced as a teammate who supported Ohtani during the postseason, and as part of the team’s broader offensive effort.

namedEntities.name: Mookie Betts
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Betts is cited as a teammate who previously supported Ohtani, illustrating team dynamics and mutual performance contributions.

namedEntities.name: Kiké Hernández
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hernández is noted as having previously achieved a three-homer game in the 2017 NLCS, placing him in historical context with Ohtani’s feat.

namedEntities.name: Chris Taylor
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Taylor is referenced as the last player to achieve a three-homer postseason game for the Dodgers, setting historical context for Ohtani’s performance.

namedEntities.name: Alex Vesia
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vesia was credited with escaping a critical jam, allowing the Dodgers to maintain their lead and contributing to the final outcome.

namedEntities.name: Blake Snell
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Snell is part of the Dodgers’ strong mound rotation that helped the team maintain a low ERA throughout the postseason.

namedEntities.name: Yoshinobu Yamamoto
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Yamamoto is part of the Dodgers’ pitching staff that collectively allowed only 10 earned runs in 10 playoff games.

namedEntities.name: Tyler Glasnow
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Glasnow is part of the Dodgers’ effective rotation that contributed to the team’s success in the postseason.

namedEntities.name: Jim Tobin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Tobin is cited as the last pitcher to hit three home runs in a game as a starter, establishing historical precedent for Ohtani’s feat.

namedEntities.name: Guy Hecker
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hecker is referenced as the previous pitcher to hit three homers in a game as a starter, dating back to 1886.

namedEntities.name: Statcast
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Statcast provided data confirming that Ohtani’s home runs were among the highest exit velocity hits in history, reinforcing the performance’s statistical significance.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic, record-breaking performance in Game 4 of the National League Championship Series, hitting three home runs and throwing a scoreless, 10-strikeout mound game against the Milwaukee Brewers. The Los Angeles Dodgers won 5-1, completing a four-game sweep and advancing to the World Series. Ohtani’s feat made him the first pitcher in 87 years to hit three homers as a starter and the first to do so in a postseason game. The performance earned him the NLCS MVP award and marked a turning point in the postseason, highlighting his two-way dominance and the team's resilience. The article emphasizes the significance of Ohtani’s performance not only for the Dodgers but also for baseball history, with historical comparisons to past greats and detailed statistical benchmarks.
title: Shohei Ohtani’s Historic Triple-Home Run and Pitching Masterpiece Powers Dodgers to World Series
